steps.title: Eat a diet of healthy
steps.content: Eat a diet of healthy , whole foods. Consume several small meals that include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean meat or protein, and dairy. Eating a variety ensures that you get numerous vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that can naturally help increase sperm motility. [1] X Research source Limit the number of processed foods you eat since these are high in sodium, refined sugar, and fats. Avoid drinking alcohol since this could reduce your sperm motility.

steps.title: Include foods that improve sperm health.
steps.content: Include foods that improve sperm health. If you're eating a variety of healthy foods, you're probably eating nutrients that improve your sperm. To be sure, include foods that are high in zinc and arginine. These will increase the amount and speed of sperm your body makes. Foods high in zinc and arginine include: [2] X Research source Seafood and shellfish such as oysters and herring Nuts and legumes such as chickpeas, beans, peas, and walnuts Lean beef, organ meats, turkey, and lamb Wheat germ Dairy Eggs Spinach, asparagus, broccoli, garlic, and carrots Bananas, pomegranates, and goji berries

steps.title: Maintain a healthy weight.
steps.content: Maintain a healthy weight . Use your height and weight to determine your body mass index (BMI). If your body mass index indicates that you're medically overweight or obese, your sperm may be poorer in quality and slower. Work with your doctor to figure a healthy body weight based on your BMI. [3] X Research source Research showed that a BMI of 25 or more reduced the amount and quality of sperm produced.

steps.title: Add a supplement that has zinc, vitamin C, carnitine, and arginine.
steps.content: Add a supplement that has zinc, vitamin C, carnitine, and arginine. Ask your doctor about adding a multi-vitamin supplement to your diet. Choose a supplement that contains zinc, vitamin C, carnitine, and arginine which studies show improve sperm motility. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source At least 2,000 to 6,000 mg of vitamin C a day to prevent sperm from clumping together and slowing down.

steps.title: Reduce the amount
steps.content: Reduce the amount of alcohol you drink. If you do drink alcohol, cut back on the amount you drink throughout the week. Research shows that drinking alcohol reduces the amount of sperm your body makes and decreases motility. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you're unsure how much alcohol you can drink without it affecting your fertility, ask your doctor to recommend a weekly limit.

steps.title: Start exercising on a regular basis.
steps.content: Start exercising on a regular basis. Exercise is associated with a number of health benefits and can help improve sperm motility by regulating hormones and contributing to weight loss. Try to get at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise and 2 strength-training sessions during the week. [6] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Moderate aerobic exercises include brisk walking, running, or bicycling. Strength-training sessions involve lifting weights to build muscle.

steps.title: Wear loose-fitting underwear to keep your testicles cool.
steps.content: Wear loose-fitting underwear to keep your testicles cool. Avoid wearing tight-fitting underwear and pants that keep fabric snug around your testicles. Instead, wear fabrics that will keep the testicles around 94 °F (34 °C) so they produce high-quality sperm. [7] X Research source If your workplace is hot or you spend a lot of time sitting down, take breaks to stand up and walk around where it's cool.

steps.title: Reduce your exposure to chemicals and toxins.
steps.content: Reduce your exposure to chemicals and toxins. Everyday products and equipment can release chemicals that increase your risk for fertility problems. Stop using or consuming the following products that can be harmful to sperm motility: [8] X Research source Plastic food storage that contains bisphenol A (BPA). Bleached paper products such as white coffee filters, toilet paper, and napkins. Chlorinated tap water and bleach. Foods that have been treated with or contain pesticides, herbicides, preservatives, and other man-made ingredients. Synthetic cosmetics, toiletries, and deodorants. Animal food products that contain synthetic hormones, such as chicken, beef, pork, and conventional dairy products such as cow’s milk. Tobacco products and secondhand smoke. Cell phone radiation [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Protect your sperm by practicing safe sex.
steps.content: Protect your sperm by practicing safe sex . Use condoms if you have more than 1 partner or stay monogamous with an uninfected partner to reduce your risk for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). STIs such as gonorrhea and chlamydia can reduce fertility and sperm motility. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you use lubrication during sex, choose a fertility-friendly lubricant (such as Pre-Seed) that's similar to the pH of the cervix or use a natural product such as canola oil or egg whites.

steps.title: Manage and reduce your stress.
steps.content: Manage and reduce your stress. The stress of trying to conceive as well as everyday life events can reduce your sperm count and slow sperm motility. Fortunately, relaxing and eliminating stress can improve your sperm fertility. To feel more relaxed, try: [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Meditation Deep breathing Physical exercise Sleeping

steps.title: Stop taking medications associated with lower fertility rates, if possible.
steps.content: Stop taking medications associated with lower fertility rates, if possible. Certain medications such as calcium channel blockers, tricyclic antidepressants, anti-androgens, and anabolic steroids can cause fertility problems. If you are currently taking medications that affect sperm motility, speak to your healthcare provider about alternative treatments that won’t slow down or reduce your sperm count. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you'll be starting chemotherapy or radiation therapy for cancer, ask your doctor about retrieving sperm before starting your courses of therapy. Then you could use the sperm for in-vitro fertilization at some point.

steps.title: Treat any underlying health conditions.
steps.content: Treat any underlying health conditions. Some health conditions can reduce your sperm count or slow the sperm down. Get a medical exam to diagnose any untreated conditions and follow your doctor's treatment plan. Sometimes, just treating the condition can improve the motility of your sperm. For example, if you have a urinary tract infection, the infection can slow down or reduce the amount of sperm you produce. Take antibiotics to treat the infection and your sperm should quickly improve.

steps.title: Ask your doctor to prescribe medication to improve sperm count.
steps.content: Ask your doctor to prescribe medication to improve sperm count. If you have a very low sperm count, talk with your doctor about taking hormones to improve your fertility. Remember to ask them about potential side effects. The doctor may prescribe: [13] X Research source Clomiphene citrate Serophene Follitropin alfa or gonal-F injections Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) Letrozole or anastrozole Exogenous androgens

steps.title: Consider in-vitro fertilization (IVF).
steps.content: Consider in-vitro fertilization (IVF). If you and your partner have been trying to conceive for at least 1 year, talk with a fertility specialist about your options. With IVF, mature eggs from your partner will be extracted and joined with your sperm in a laboratory. The fertilized egg will be inserted into your partner's uterus where it will hopefully implant. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your sperm is simply slow, the doctor may recommend intrauterine insemination (IUI) where your sperm is injected into your partner's uterus. If it's timed when your partner is ovulating, your partner might be able to conceive.
